comments.text:
+Laurie Harding-Russell Not really. At all. I am pretty sure you know that 
and are intentionally being simple here though. Genes are transcribed into 
RNA, which can do all kinds of things, including regulation of cell 
activities. Some of this RNA is mRNA, which can get translated into 
polypeptides. Proteins are composed of one or more polypeptides, and 
enzymes are one type of protein--the type that catalyzes biochemical 
reactions. There are definitely other kinds of proteins--e.g. hemoglobin (2 
copies each of 2 different polypeptides). Hemoglobin binds oxygen so that 
your red blood cells can distribute it throughout your tissues. There are 
proteins that transport things from point A to point B, proteins that color 
things and seem to do nothing else, proteins that stabilize the structure 
of things, etc.
Non-protein molecules can also affect the production of things like 
steroids. For example, saturated fats lower transcription levels of LDL 
receptors, resulting in less LDL in your cells and more in your blood, 
which opens the door for it to get oxidized/glycosylated/etc. and 
contribute to atherosclerosis. It is the cholesterol inside LDL that your 
body can use to synthesize steroid hormones.

Also, gene therapy tends to not be permanent either, for two big reasons:
1--unlike bacteria which have circular DNA, humans have chromosomes shaped 
like sticks, and the therapeutic DNA doesn't really integrate into that 
very well. It hangs around for a while and then gets degraded by enzymes 
that are supposed to degrade loose chunks of DNA.
2--you actually have a complete copy of all of your DNA in every single 
cell (except sperm/eggs etc.where it gets weird) in your body, but the 
therapy isn't going to successfully reach every last cell you've got. So 
you'll be fixing the defect in some cells but not in others. Usually, the 
disease reduces in effect but does not go away completely. Now, some cells 
are still dividing and some aren't. Some of the ones you fix will divide, 
and some of the ones you didn't fix will divide. How many of each may be up 
to random chance, so the proportion of cells you have at any given time 
during the duration of effect for gene therapy is not guaranteed to be in 
your favor--i.e. you're not guaranteed to have more of the ones that are 
expressing the fixed proteins than you are ones that are expressing 
defective proteins. This is one of the same reasons why metastatic cancer 
sucks so bad. It usually originates in cells that are still dividing and 
then go on to divide without limit or regulation. And when it can do that 
anywhere in your body regardless of where it originated, you tend to die 
from it.
comments.author: Nyonics

comments.text:
No, genes create enzymes which in turn control the production of everything 
including steroids. Gene therapy would modify the "Code" of your DNA to 
increase steroid production in your cells. Unfortunately we don't really 
understand the DNA or the "code" well enough to edit it at this point in 
time to do such specific thing.

comments.text:
+Hunter McCarthy
Yes they do, though not in the way you'd expect. Steroids activate a class 
of cellular receptors called 'Nuclear receptors' which are responsible for 
transcribing several genes (usually the steroid binds the receptor and 
activates it, then the receptor binds to a transcription factor and 
activates that). The transcription factor then binds to the promoter 
regions of its 'target genes' and transcribes them, in other words making 
an mRNA copy that will form the template for the production of a protein.

It obviously depends on the type of receptor activated by the steroid 
(usually steroids target receptors with anti-inflammatory properties, such 
as PPARgamma) and for how long you take the steroids. But if you took them 
for the rest of your life they would permanently affect your bodies ability 
to become inflammed.

you're not able to afford them, then your limbs will effectively become 
paperweights and you may end up with less than you even had before. If 
people didn't like big business before, they won't be fond of my General 
Motors-brand lower arm and hand assembly, or my Microsoft flash memory 
enhancer. 

Besides, only the rich would be able to afford such modification anyway. 
Same with anti-aging or anything of that nature. 

Genetic modification? Maybe, but I'm generally fine with what I've got 
right now. Any additional increases in Human modification would likely have 
a heavy degree of privatization attached to it.

comments.text:
+edc2879 Though as someone who self-identifies as a transhumanist I, 
ironically, am against excessive genetic modifications on humans. Anything 
beyond improving health and potentially other things like lifespans, 
intelligence (though remember a lot of that also comes from 
nurture/learning), etc. are fine. But more radical things easily breach 
morphological freedom. Though I do agree with the idea of using this 
technology to improve survival in space habitats (and potentially other 
environments).

But we should still remember that we are a long way before anything of this 
scale occurs. We should also remember that there is not really a guarantee 
for some potential uses of technology that other transhumanists like to 
posit. *Science takes time and results are not always like what lay people 
are hopeful for (though, sometimes, unexpected results might lead to 
something potentially better).* The more radical stuff like "mind 
uploading" is still very far off--assuming it is possible in the first 
place (I'm talking about the possibility of it being done, the 
philosophical issues are yet another can of worms).

Interestingly, Transhumanist thought has matured quite a lot recently in 
terms of bioethics (the last of your links may be an example, but I'm 
skeptical since they mentioned "the singularity"). Though one should note 
this is the direction the movement is going within academia. The general 
public scale of it, IMHO, seems to be dangerously veering off into silly 
wish-fulfillment/pseudo religious things like "singularitarianism." 
Additionally, the movement has grown increasingly political with some 
transhumanist notions slowly becoming more common within Libertarian 
thought ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libertarian_transhumanism ) and the 
recent "Techno Progressivism" ( 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Techno-progressivism ) on the opposite 
political spectrum.
comments.author: Elround4

comments.text:
+joseph clisham the limits of this technique (using a virus to transmit the 
gene of interest to the host) are related to the viruses themselves, 
because most of them trigger an immune response that will kill and remove 
the "infected" cell from the body. Another limitation is the stability of 
the replacing gene in our chromosome. After a few cycle of cellular 
replication, this gene might be kicked out of the chromosome and thus the 
therapeutic effect would be lost. A third limitation is the amount of 
information that those viruses can carry. Some of those viruses can't 
handle big genes with a lot of information and that could be a problem for 
big genes that have to be replaced . =)

comments.text:
+SubjectRedstone This is a pervasive myth. It is only a myth, though. There 
have been several types of cancers documented in sharks, as well as 
bacterial and parasitic infections. Sharks contain a molecule called 
squalamine which (possibly) makes sharks immune to viruses, however, this 
suggests they have been affected by viruses in the past, as they wouldn't 
have evolved anti-viral properties. Sharks also don't have bones, they only 
have cartilage, which doesn't have any blood vessels. This could make them 
resistant to some cancers, as cancers need blood to survive.

Their immune systems are impressive, but not perfect. :)

The only sort of genetic enhancements I'd support would be asthetic ones. 
Hair type, color. Eye color, etc.

Being able to augment physical and mental attributes would have dramatic 
repercussions on society. Plus.. it would be plain unfair to people who 
can't afford or just don't want the procedure.﻿
top_comment.author: r315r4z0r

comments.text:
+r315r4z0r
I agree, but I doubt it'd ever happen. The NR2B gene they stuck in the mice 
is a subunit of the NMDA receptor, a receptor important in memory and 
cognition. However, it's also the NR2-form (out of NR2A-D) that results in 
the most damage during disease like Alzheimer's when the glutamatergic 
system (uncluding NMDA receptors) is hijacked.

There are too many genes involved in cogition/memory, it would be stupid to 
think we could change it with a modification to a single gene. We'd have to 
change many hundreds, in which case the cancer chance increases, until 
eventually a genetic boost results in cancer 100% of the time. Same with 
strength and speed, though these are easier to achieve than cognitive 
enhancements.

I'm guessing you may have played Deus Ex, which dives heavily into this 
debate, and I think I have to fundamentally agree with you.
comments.author: shaunpaulcroft

comments.text:
Because aesthetics don't drive your capabilities. Who cares if you can't 
afford an aesthetic procedure and someone else can? It's not unfair because 
it has no impact on either person in terms of capabilities. No one said 
anything about curing diseases either since that falls into the same 
category. It doesn't matter if you don't get a procedure to prevent a 
genetic disorder and someone else does because in the end it's one less 
person who is sick.

The problem with capability enhancement procedures is that it does cause a 
rift between individuals. People without alterations would be inferior to 
people with alterations. It could possibly even amount to people having to 
be required to have genetic procedures to reach certain places in 
society... like to have a specific job or to be allowed to do a specific 
activity.

It would introduce way more harm than good.

comments.text:
I disagree.  Greed, territoriality, aggression, and prejudice are very 
natural for us.  Disease, such as cancer, Alzheimer's, malaria, etc. are 
natural for us.  _Death_ is not only natural, it is inevitable.  True, some 
of those things may still serve *some* useful purpose, but they are not the 
best things we have available.  Natural does not necessarily mean good, 
just the very specific circumstances that we evolved with.
Making ourselves better, and creating our own natures (something we have 
been doing since we first evolved) is not something bad, and I might go so 
far as to say that that *is* natural for us.  I see nothing wrong with 
genetic modification, once we can ensure it is safe.

or your mind? Can You Genetically Enhance
Yourself?

First we should start by treating or preventing
whatever illness we might already have using

Gene Therapy. Let's...draw this one out...with
asapSCIENCE!

Asap: Simply put, Gene Therapy is when you
insert a correct gene, that single unit of

hereditary information, in place of a missing
or broken one - fixing that strand of DNA.

The common method of delivery is inserting
the genetic information into a virus, using
it as a vehicle or vector, to enter the cell.

Gene Therapy has been used to treat diseases
like Severe Combined Immunodeficiency, leukemia,

and Leber's Congential Amaurosis - a disease
that causes loss of vision.

If we can replace certain genes, could we
genetically enhance our own to increase something

like strength? Well, we already have...in
mice. Called "Schwarzenegger Mice", scientists

injected a gene that created a specific protein,
IGF-1, to increase their muscle mass around

40%. As they aged, their strength stayed the
same as when they were young.

But what if we want speed? There's mice for
that too. They were given a gene that encoded

a fat burning protein creating "Marathon Mice"
that could run faster and twice the distance
of normal ones.
And then there is the mind...

Asap: In 1999, researchers from Princeton
University genetically modified mice, called

"Doogie", to increase their intelligence.
By inserting one certain gene, NR2B which

stimulates a receptor in the hippocampus,
the mice could associate one event to another

better and faster, increasing their memory
and ability to learn. Not only that, but as

the mice grew older their intelligence was
mostly unchanged.

Strength, speed and intelligence are only
some of the of the genetic modifications successfully

performed on animals. There are goats that
produce spider silk, hypoallergenic cats,

and a variety of glow-in-the-dark animals
but my favorite is the GloFish.

GloFish were one of the first genetically
modified animals to be sold as pets. They

gain their color by being given fluorescent
protein genes that are found in things like
jellyfish and coral.

GloFish are patented, trademarked and owned
by a company...but if we can modify and enhance

animals, and then market and sell them, how
long until I can go to the store, buy some

new genes to inject and make myself stronger?
And that's where things get complicated...

Asap: Lets say you want to be taller, well,
there are over 180 genes involved in height.

Which ones do we change? Even when scientists
and doctors know what to modify it might end

up changing something else, for the worse.
We can't directly control where the gene goes

- it can attach, disrupting other genes. For
example, out of 30 people treated for SCID,
5 developed cancer.

When experimenting on human beings, the margins
for error are a lot less than with animal

test subjects. So we might not be able to
inject genetic power-ups right now and witness

immediate changes like in BioShock, but survival
of the fittest isn't solely about who is the

strongest or fastest, it's who is best adapted
to their environment. And we live in a time

where we are increasingly adapting the environment
to us and with that intelligence has become
one of the strongest assets.

increase your offsprings' intelligence? Follow
